reasoning: [Specific Program Not Verified] Paper mentions 'Takaful' but search could not confirm this as graduation program: Perplexity search result: The Takaful (and Karama) program in Egypt is a national cash transfer program launched in 2015 with support from the World Bank. Its primary function is to provide conditional cash transfers to vulnerable families to help cover basic needs and promote human capital through healthcare and educational access[3][6][7]. Although there is an ongoing policy discussion about integrating graduation and economic inclusion elements into the program, and some pilots or recommendations suggest adding these elements in the future[2][4], Takaful itself does not currently implement the full graduation approach. Specifically, it does not provide productive assets, nor does it use the multi-component approach of graduation programs (asset transfer, coaching, and cash stipend together) as core program elements. A related, but distinct, program called 'Forsa' provides productive assets and economic inclusion interventions to either Takaful recipients or near-eligible participants, but this is not part of the standard Takaful program. Therefore, Takaful is not itself a graduation or multi-component poverty program, but rather a classic conditional cash transfer scheme. | Graduation: NO, Cash: YES, Assets: NO | Confidence: HIGH | Sources: https://mped.gov.eg/singlenews?id=6196&type=next&lang=en, https://www.worldbank.org/en/news/feature/2018/11/15/the-story-of-takaful-and-karama-cash-transfer-program, https://egyptssp.ifpri.info/2025/01/14/egypts-experience-bridging-cash-transfers-and-an-economic-inclusion-program-for-sustainable-social-protection/
